trial_identification.studytitle: Azithromycin in older people with airway disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A double-blind randomised controlled study of the anti-inflammatory effects of azithromycin 250mg daily for 12 weeks in adults with symptomatic neutrophilic airway disease

interventions.interventions: Azithromycin 250mg daily for 12 weeks, by oral administration.
interventions.comparator: Placebo (lactose) 250mg daily for 12 weeks, by oral administration.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Interleukin-8 (IL-8) concentrations in sputum supernatant, detected via the use of laboratory Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) kits.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Sputum bacterial load, which will be assessed by a Pathology service through counting and identifying bacterial colonies in sputum samples.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Neutrophil concentrations in sputum, which will be established through a differential cell count of muco-cellular clumps in sputum samples.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Neutrophil elastase levels in sputum, which will be established through the use of a commercially available neutrophil elastase immunocapture activity assay kit.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) as a percentage of participants' predicted FEV1 (FEV1 %pred), measured through the use of spirometry.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Short acting beta agonist use, assessed by participant self-report of average short acting beta agonist use per day and week.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life, assessed by administration of the Juniper Quality of Life Questionnaire.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at randomisation and at the end of treatment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Symptomatic stable asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), increased sputum neutrophils.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Hypersensitivity to macrolides, other respiratory disease, taking macrolide, tetracycline, antibiotic or oral corticosteroid in past month, taking antacid treatment, taking medication that prolongs the heart's corrected QT interval (QTc), current smoking, pregnancy, impaired liver function.

trial_design.concealment: Randomised by pharmacy using random number list, concealed from investigators by manufacturing identical active and placebo tablets and labelling in a non-identifying manner.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of the study is to further the identification of effective treatment options for people with obstructive airway diseases, such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and neutrophilic inflammation. The study will investigate the anti-inflammatory effect of a macrolide antibiotic, azithromycin, on airway inflammation, symptoms, quality of life and lung function. It is hypothesised that azithromycin therapy will reduce bacteria in the sputum and inflammatory cells of participants with neutrophilic airway disease.
